US MARKET WRAP 26 April 2019: Stocks close at new record high after solid Q1 GDP
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries up, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US Headline GDP beats, internals softer, Trump jawbones oil down, Amazon up on earnings, Chevron mixed, Exxon missed.

* NEXT WEEK: Sunday: Spanish Election. Monday: EZ consumer confidence; US PCE/personal spending. Tuesday: German unemployment; EZ flash Q1 GDP, regional EZ CPIs; Canada GDP; US consumer confidence, pending home sales, Chicago PMI; NZ employment. Wednesday: Europe Labour Day Holiday; UK, US mfg PMI; US ADP employment, construction spending, ISM mfg, FOMC. Thursday: China Caixin mfg PMI; EZ mfg PMI; UK construction PMI; BOE QIR; US factory orders. Friday: UK, US Services PMI; EZ CPI; US nonfarm payrolls, ISM non-mfg. Click here to read full report.

* US GDP DATA: US GDP rose 3.2% annualised in Q1, beating the consensus view of 2.3%. However, underneath the bonnet, the details weren't as great: the GDP deflator and PCE deflator were below consensus (next week's PCE's data will give a timelier look at the underlying picture). Net trade was a contributor in Q1, but by less than expected. Consumption was stronger than foreseen. Government spending missed, dragged lower by non-defence spending. Capex was mixed. Net/net, analysts at Pantheon say it was still a strong report, reminding us that Q1 tends to be under reported. "The problem for the Fed now, though, is that if growth continues at anything like this pace, the labour market will tighten much further this year, and the question of rate hikes will be back on the agenda," Pantheon Macroeconomics says, and it thinks GDP growth will be very different in terms of the details in Q2: "consumption will be much stronger, while trade and inventories will likely be drags, and capex is a wild card - overall we expect a 2-to-3% rate." Pantheon reminds us that inflation data is key for the Fed, and with the quarterly core PCE increase signalling gains averaging just 0.07% in both February and March, it completes a run of three substantially sub-trend readings. "The numbers likely will rebound in Q2 but even so the Fed is very unlikely to face overshooting inflation this year," Pantheon argues, "pressure on policymakers will come from the labour market, with unemployment likely to hit new lows while wage growth hits new highs, rather than the contemporaneous inflation data."

* TRADE: US President Trump suggested that Chinese President Xi will be visiting the White House ‘soon’. Subsequently SCMP reported that Chinese President Xi could travel to the US to sign a trade deal as soon as June, if the two sides finalise a trade deal. From a markets-perspective, there is an expectation that a trade deal can be wrapped up by the end of May, following a pushing back of the 'deadline' by end-March. Commentary from both sides continues to strike a constructive tone, however, little by way of new details has been revealed, which could explain why markets are less-responsive to trade headlines, of late, particularly as US earnings season gets underway, and the macro focus is now falling on global growth metrics as major central banks err dovish.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 1.91 LOWER AT USD 63.30/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 2.20 LOWER AT USD 72.15/BBL. In the European morning, crude saw downside which analysts struggled to explain. There were some unsubstantiated reports that the US was to give China a waiver to allow it to continue buying Iranian oil. However, reputable desks suggested it might be a short-term technical correction after the push higher stalled, following the US decision to not grant sanctions waivers to buyers of Iranian crude. US President Trump later said that he had been in touch with OPEC and told them to bring oil prices down, which was met with downticks in the crude complex (OPEC chief Barkindo and the Saudis denied this). Later, Trump officials commented said there would be no short-term waiver for China’s purchasing of crude from Iran and that the US expects China to comply with the sanctions, as doing business with the US should be more important to China than with Iran. Citi's analysts says "the track record on [Trump’s] efforts to jawbone OPEC into raising production has been mixed at best," adding that for now, "it simply looks as though the downdraft is more related to the build in US crude stocks for last week and 'profit taking run amok' than from any bearish fundamental development." The bank notes that US GDP data was stronger than expected, with the S&P 500 little changed on the day, and the US dollar index moderately lower, not anything that would normally signal a wider risk-off trade flow. Baker Hughes US Rig Count data for the week saw total rigs -21 at 991, oil rigs -20 at 805 (second week oil drillers have cut rigs, and it was the steepest cut in weekly oil rigs since January; for April, as a whole, drillers have now cut rigs for a fifth straight month), and gas rigs -1 at 186.

* SPX +0.5% at 2940, NDX +0.1% at 7826, DJI +0.3% at 26542. SECTORS: Communications +0.5%, Cons Discretionary +0.9%, Cons Staples +0.9%, Energy -1.2%, Financials +0.9%, Healthcare +0.9%, Industrials +0.7%, Materials %, Tech -0.4%, Telecoms +0.7%, Utilities +0.2%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Amazon (AMZN) traded choppy but finished higher after the ecommerce giant reported earnings that beat both top and bottom lines whilst announcing that it would work on reducing Prime free delivery time from 2 to 1-day shipping. Reports emerged that Intel (INTC) and Apple (AAPL) held talks last year for Apple to buy Intel’s smartphone modem business with Goldman Sachs hired to sell the unit which could reportedly fetch a few billion dollars. Walmart (WMT) shares fell following Amazon’s (AMZN) announcement. Ford Motor Co. (Ford) was the top performer in the S&P500 after the automaker reported a significant beat on both top and bottom-line expectations whilst reporting strong F-Series pick-up truck sales in the US. Automakers more generally outperformed, with General Motors (GM) also trading higher on the day. Colgate Palmolive (CL) traded higher after the consumer product maker reported earnings that were largely in line with expectations and the CEO expressed pleasure with organic sales growth in both emerging and developed markets. The positive mood helped lift the wider consumer staples sector, with P&G (PG) and Kimberly Clark (KMB), also finishing higher on the day. On a less positive note, Intel Corp’s (INTC) share price was hit despite beating analyst’s top and bottom-line expectations, after the chipmaker revised down Q2 and FY guidance. American Airlines (AAL) opened lower after the airline lowered full year guidance, saying it had cancelled 1200 planes due to the Boeing (BA) 737 Max grounding. Exxon Mobil (XOM) traded lower throughout the session after reported earnings that missed profit and revenue expectations. Chevron (CVX), who reported mixed earnings and released no extra colour regarding the Anadarko bid, also moved lower. More broadly, Energy stocks, including the above and Conoco Phillips (COP), were dragged lower as crude prices fell by north of 3% on the day. Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) shares fell after the food processor reported earnings that missed on both top and bottom-line expectations.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 9 TICKS HIGHER AT123-21+. Despite a solid GDP headline, the Treasury complex caught a bid in wake of the Q1 report, with analysts suggesting some of the internals of the report were not as encouraging as the headline. Yields were lower across the curve, and by settlement, the curve had bull steepened. The focus now turns to next week's FOMC, (virtually no chance of a hike - will the Fed acknowledge upward data surprises, and recharacterize its view of the economy? as well as the April Employment Situation Report. 

* FX WRAP: USD fell as the market shrugged of GDP beat, focused on weak PCE data, hold majority of week’s gains around 98.00 handle. EUR The eurozone currency strengthened vs major counterparts but upside was limited amid EU political uncertainty (the S&P review on Italy, Spanish elections on Sunday). GBP reclaimed 1.2900 handle amid dollar weakness, but downside risk remains amid mounting pressure on UK PM May and mixed reports regarding cross-party talks. JPY largely ignored disappointing industrial production data miss with USDJPY finishing flat ahead of Japan’s Golden Week holidays and the conflicting forces of dollar weakness vs mild risk on sentiment. NZD gained early on strong trade data, reclaiming the 0.6650 handle vs USD and further extended gains after soft US PCE data. SEK strengthened vs both USD and EUR and has now retraced 50% of yesterday’s post dovish Riksbank losses on strong retail sales data, which also allowed the SEK to outperform its Scandinavian counterpart the NOK. CAD reversed early crude related weakness after soft US PCE data spurred USD outflows.

* WEEKLY FX RECAP: USD: The Dollar remains on track to seal a solid week, with the DXY all but 100 ticks higher than where it started when posting a fresh 2019 high (98.346 vs 97.369), and just over a full point above worst levels (97.254). The bulk of the Greenback’s gains have been forged by virtue of weakness elsewhere as the list of global Central Banks shying away from further policy normalisation and/or switching towards a more dovish stance grows, but tighter US liquidity and a relatively punitive cost of carry allied to talk of unhedged US Treasury longs and the crude rally all compounded the Buck’s bull run. However, the rally has lost some momentum in wake of benign PCE price metrics that have taken the shine off stellar Q1 growth that was boosted by inventories and exports vs less robust domestic consumption and fixed investment. The index is back down around 98.000 and retesting technical support just under the big figure at 97.961 before a key downside chart point at 97.693.

*CAD/SEK/TRY/RUB: Aside from the aforementioned broad Usd strength, the Loonie, Swedish Crown, Lira and Rouble have all had to contend with unexpected monetary policy twists to varying degrees. In short, the BoC and CBRT both surprised by removing guidance or a pledge to hike, while the Riksbank delayed further tightening to end 2019 or early next year from H2 this year, trimmed its repo rate path and unveiled a Sek45 bn bond purchase program to begin in July 2019 and end in December 2020. Last, but not least, the CBR signalled conditions for easing later in Q2 or Q3 based on predictions that inflation will return to target and its assessment that previous rises in benchmark rates should be enough to achieve the price mandate. Usd/Cad currently towards the upper end of the weekly 1.3330-1.3520 range, Eur/Sek close to 10.5800 vs 10.4475 at one stage and 10.6655 post-Riksbank (when Usd/Sek hit peaks not seen since 2003), with the Krona deriving some traction from forecast-beating Swedish retail sales at the tail end of the week. However, the Lira is still languishing near the base of its 5.9785-8030 trading band as Turkey’s AKP continues to contest the results of regional elections and relations with the US remained strained on Russian S-400 and Iranian oil sanction waivers. Similarly, Usd/Rub is now around 64.7225 within 64.9720-63.6250 extremes as a pretty sharp turnaround in crude prices adds to the dovish CBR shift.

*NZD/AUD: Conversely, the Kiwi has staged a stellar recovery from its depths vs US and Aussie counterparts, with Nzd/Usd back to within a whisker of best levels between 0.6689-0.6578 boundaries and Aud/Nzd down around 1.0560 vs virtually 1.0700 at one stage. The catalysts, much better than consensus NZ trade data and ANZ consumer sentiment plus pretty upbeat comments from RBNZ Governor Orr (not perturbed about weaker growth given tight jobs situation, albeit maintaining scope to ease if necessary). In contrast, the Aussie is lagging circa 0.7060 vs almost a big figure higher at one stage, though off lows of 0.6985 in wake of much softer than anticipated Q1 CPI data that heightens calls for an RBA cut next month and another before the year ends.

*EUR/GBP: Both benefiting from post-US data Dollar pull-back and perhaps more pre-weekend/April 30/Japanese holiday positioning, as the single currency extends its rebound from new 2019 lows of 1.1112 towards 1.1175 and Cable consolidates its return to the 1.2900+ area from 1.2863 when the Usd was really in demand. Nevertheless, the Euro and Pound are still well down from 1.1260+ and 1.3000+ highs (which were also not far from ‘opens’) amidst ongoing downbeat German/Eurozone growth impulses and ECB policy implications or perceptions, Italian fiscal/economic and political issues ahead of S&P’s latest ratings review and Spanish election uncertainty. Meanwhile, Brexit developments have been thin on the ground, and in fact PM May is now highly unlikely to bring the WA back for a 4th attempt to gain Parliament approval next week.

*CHF/JPY: The Franc and Yen have endured volatile weeks within 1.0230-0130 and 112.40-111.40 respective ranges with latest SNB promptings about the need to keep sub-zero rates and currency intervention going heeded if not sparking a response in similar vein to a fairly subtle tweak to BoJ guidance. However, the so called ‘safe-havens’ are ending Friday’s session firmer for choice amidst concerns that the lengthier than normal Golden Week break in Japan (10 days) could see market conditions and volumes return to flash crash type levels if some trigger or a real risk averse event sets off another flight-to-quality. On that note, next week’s highlights include the FOMC, BoE super Thursday and NFP on Friday.

subject: PRIMER: S&P review on Italy after the bell
analysis_details:
• S&P will on Friday review its credit rating on Italy. Currently, Fitch and S&P have Italy at IG but with a negative outlook (Moody's has Italy as an IG with stable rating).
  • Morgan Stanley notes that the ECB and Bank of Italy hold around EUR 375bln of BTPs (around 19% of total outstanding BTPs). Foreign ownership of BTPs has been steadily declining since 2011 (from around 47% of total outstanding BTPs, to the current 32%).
  • Given that the ECB defines sub-investment grade based on the highest rating of the four rating agencies (Moody's, S&P, Fitch, DBRS), in practice, all four agencies have to give Italy’s sovereign debt a junk rating for it to drop out of the ECB's portfolio, Morgan Stanley notes, and on aggregate, the bank believes that these agencies' rating of Italian sovereign debt is still some way off junk, as agencies rarely move more than one notch at a time, and "As such, the probability of seeing three of the four rating agencies giving Italian sovereign debt junk status is small in the near term."
  • But the bank warns that should S&P withdraw its IG rating in the medium-term, Italian sovereign markets would be volatile. "In this case, we would regard Italian banks as providing the guidance for EURUSD," Morgan Stanley says, "given Italian banks' substantial BTP holdings, an increase in sovereign risk is likely to spill over into bank credit. Italy’s private credit growth may find it harder to recover, keeping Italy on the economic back foot for longer."

Fixed and FX latest: knee-jerk moves after US data
content: US GDP and PCE metrics portray the best of both worlds in fundamental terms, but the bumper growth and slow inflation dynamic does not change the Fed policy outlook so initial reactions have been faded and reversed relatively swiftly. Indeed, slides to new session lows or revisits to previous troughs in bonds have subsequently seen Gilts and US Treasuries print fresh intraday peaks at 127.87 (+1/4 point on the day vs -14 ticks) and 123-23+ (from 123-09), while the DXY is now struggling to retain 98.000 and hold above chart support having claimed a new, albeit marginal new 2019 peak at 98.346.

content:
DOW

  • Aflac (AFL) (Financials/Insurance) (USD) Q1 EPS 1.12 (exp. 1.06), revenue 5.7bln (exp. 5.49bln).
  • American Airlines Group (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) (USD) Q1 EPS 0.52 (exp. 0.51), revenue 10.6bln (exp. 10.6bln). AAL says it cancelled 1,200 flights due to the grounding of the Boeing (BA) 737 Max. AAL also lowered FY19 adj EPS view, now sees 4.00-6.00 (prev. 5.50-7.50).
  • Aon PLC (AON) (Financials/Insurance Brokers) (USD) Q1 EPS 3.31 (exp. 3.31), revenue 3.1bln (exp. 3.22bln).
  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) (USD) Design team is losing several veterans, WSJ reports.
  • Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) (USD) Q1 EPS USD 0.46 (exp. 0.61), revenue 15.3bln (exp. 16.23bln). CEO says Q1 was more challenging than initially expected, citing impact from severe weather in North America, and the ethanol industry environment limited margins and opportunities. CEO continues to see progress on our key imperatives for 2019. However, the continued advancement of our strategy, combined with anticipated resolution of the US-China trade situation, and an expected acceleration of soybean meal demand, leaves CEO optimistic for H2, remains committed to FY earnings comparable to or higher than 2018.
  • Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) (Financials/Multi-Sector Holdings) could buy back up to USD 100bln, FT reports. No timeframe was provided, and Buffet dismissed the idea of paying a dividend. Berkshire repurchased USD 1.3bln of its stock last year.
  • Capital One (COF) (Financials/Credit Services) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 2.90 (exp. 2.70), revenue 7.08bln (exp. 7.03bln). Q1 net interest margin -10bps at 6.86%. Q1 net charge-offs of 1.6bln.
  • Chevron Corp (CVX) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) (USD) Q1 EPS 1.39 vs. (exp. 1.29), revenue 34bln (exp. 37.43bln). CVX said Q1 US upstream production 884k BOE/D (vs. 733k Y/Y), Q1 international upstream production 2.15mln BOE/D (vs. 2.12mln Y/Y), Q1 international downstream total refined product sales 1.42mln BPD (vs 1.44mln Y/Y). Production increased in Permian, volumes +7% Y/Y. Q1 earnings decline Y/Y on lower crude prices and weaker downstream. No major colour on Anardarko bid, CEO repeats it will unlock significant value for shareholders.
  • Colgate-Palmolive Co (CL) (Consumer Staples/Household Products) (USD) Q1 EPS 0.67 (exp. 0.66), revenue 3.884bln (exp. 3.86bln); sees low-single-digit decline in EPS in FY19, and sees FY19 net sales flat to up low-single-digits. CEO was pleased with the improvement in organic sales growth, with emerging markets and developed markets each growing, and believes plans to accelerate growth are beginning to pay off, as the stronger organic sales growth in the quarter had a better balance between pricing and volume growth than Q4.
  • Discover Financial Services (DFS) (Financials/Consumer Finance) (USD) Q1 EPS 2.15 (exp. 2.02), revenue 2.76bln (exp. 2.76bln).
  • Disney (DIS), Sinclair (SBGI), Amazon (AMZN) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) NY Post reports Amazon may join Sinclair to bid on regional sports networks.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) (USD) Q1 EPS 0.55 (exp. 0.69), revenue 63.63bln (exp. 64.82bln) Q1 GAAP earnings USD 2.35bln vs. Prev. USD 4.65bln. Q1 oil equivalent production 4mln BPD, +2%. Co. states that weak industry fuel margins impacted Q1 downstream results. Co. has begun construction at a new unit at their Beaumont, Texas refinery which will increase crude refining capacity at the facility by 250k BPD.
  • Ford (F) (Consumer Cyclicals/Autos) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 0.44 (exp. 0.26), revenue 41.96bln (exp. 37.05bln). Lower profit for Q1 but beat the street view; F-Series pickup truck sales strong in the US. Restructuring the business includes cutting costs by 11bln by 2021 and overhauling its product line up. CEO noted "volatile environment with very strong competition" and said Q1 was likely Ford's best for the year. Made a profit in Europe but struggling in China. CFO said Q1 market share fell to 5.9% from 6.5%. The tone on of the call emphasised Ford's focus on action and accelerated execution this year, some analysts said. Separately, DOJ has opened a criminal probe on the automaker for US emissions certificate process.
  • Fortive Corp (FTV) (Technology/Scientific & Technical Instruments) (USD) Q1 EPS USD 0.43 (exp. 0.69), revenue 1.59bln (exp. 1.62bln).
  • Intel (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) (USD): Q1 adj EPS 0.89 (exp. 0.87), revenue 16.1bln (exp. 16.02bln). Poor guidance: sees Q2 adj EPS/revenue at 0.89 and 15.6bln (exp. 1.01 and 16.86bln), sees FY adj EPS/revenue at 4.35 and 69bln (exp. 4.50 and 71.04bln).
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) (USD) Awarded 723.55mln US Army contract modification to procure a variety of Hellfire II missile variants.
  • LyondellBasell (LYB) (Materials/Specialty Chemicals) (USD) Q1 EPS 2.19 (exp. 2.19), revenue 8.78bln (exp. 9.36bln).
  • Merck (MRK) (Health Care/Drug Manufacturers) KEYTRUDA met a primary endpoint in pivotal Phase 3 KEYNOTE-062 trial.
  • Parker-Hannifin (PH) (Industrials/Diversified Industrials) (USD) raises quarterly dividend 16% to 0.88 (prev. 0.76).
  • Republic Services (RSG) (Industrials/Waste Management) (USD) Q1 EPS 0.73 (exp. 0.72), revenue 2.47bln (exp. USD 2.5bln). Reiterates 2019 EPS guidance.

S&P 500

  • Ventas Inc (VTR) (Real Estate/Health Care REITs) (USD) Q1 adj FFO/share 0.99 (exp. 0.96), revenue 0.943bln (exp. 0.96bln).
  • Weyerhaeuser (WY) (Real Estate/Specialized REITS) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 0.11 (exp. 0.09), revenue 1.64bln (exp. 1.67bln). CEO anticipates modest Y/Y housing growth, sees building activity accelerating with improved weather and continued macroeconomic stability.
  • Whirlpool (WHR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Appliances) urges shareholders to reject 'mini-tender' offer by Peer & Peri.
  • Zimmer Biomet Holdings Inc (ZBH) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 1.87 (exp. 1.86), revenue 1.976bln (exp. 1.96bln). Reiterates FY19 adj EPS view at 7.70-7.90 (exp. 7.80).

NASDAQ 100

  • Align (ALGN) (Health Care/Medical Devices) CEO says co. seeing incredible demand, and is only 10% penetrated in the market.
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) (USD): Q1 EPS 7.09 (exp. 4.72), revenue 59.7bln (exp. 59.65bln); guides Q2 revenue 59.5bln-63.5bln (exp. 62.4bln). Working on making Prime free 2-day standard shipping into free 1-day shipping. Amazon Web Services revenue grew 41% in the first quarter. Separately, less than a week after launching its free music streaming service, AMZN is readying a hi-def music streaming service, according to Music Business Worldwide.
  • Celgene (CELG) (Health Care/Drug Manufacturers) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 2.55 (exp. 2.49), Revenue 4.03bln (exp. 4.02bln); reaffirms FY19 EPS at 10.60-10.80 (exp. 10.70), and reaffirms FY19 revenue at 17bln-17.2bln (exp. 17.11bln). CEO continues to see positive momentum into the expected closing of the Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) transaction in Q319. Elsewhere, Celgene and Acceleron Pharma (XLRN) announced that CELG has submitted a Marketing Authorization Application to the European Medicines Agency for luspatercept, for the treatment of anaemia.
  • Cerner (CERN) (Information Technology/Health Information Services) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 0.61 (exp. 0.61), revenue 1.39bln (exp. 1.39bln).
  • Ctrip (CTRP) (Consumer Cyclical/Leisure) announces share exchange transaction with Naspers; Naspers will exchange its stake in MakeMyTrip for newly issued shares in Ctrip.
  • Facebook (FB) (Information Technology/Internet Content & Information) NY AG to investigate FB's unauthorized collection of 1.5mln+ users' email address books.
  • Illumina (ILMN) (Healthcare/Diagnostics & Research) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 1.60 (exp. 1.36), revenue 0.846bln (exp. USD 0.84bln). Raises FY19 adj EPS view to 6.63-6.73 (prev. 6.50-6.60; exp. 6.53). Reiterates FY19 revenue view +13%-14% (exp. 3.78bln). EPS view reflects the favourable impact of the Helix deconsolidation.
  • Kraft Heinz (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) is struggling to sell its Maxwell House coffee brand, which has been for sale since Feb. Buyers who have met management have not followed up with bids, with one issue being the USD 2.5bln price tag, NY Post reports.
  • Starbucks (SBUX) (Consumer Cyclical/Restaurants) (USD) Q2 EPS 0.52 vs. exp. 0.56, revenue 6.3bln vs. exp. 6.32bln. Raises FY EPS view to 2.75-2.79 (previous 2.68-2.73, consensus 2.71). Beat estimates for quarterly SSS. Will have Nitro Cold Brew in all US stores by end of FY19. Says its 'well-positioned' for long-term growth in China. Says expanded retail in the qtr with Nestle (NSRGY, NESN) deal.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Autos) Citron Research’s chief Andrew Left is no longer long nor short of the stock. 
  • T-Mobile (TMUS) (Communication Services/Telecoms Services) (USD) Q1 Adj EBITDA 3.28bln (Exp. 3.21bln), revenue 11.08bln (Exp. 11.00bln); results exceed expectations. Postpaid metrics also strong: postpaid phone net adds of 656k (exp. 612k), but prepaid net additions at 69k missed (exp. 119k). Co. increased 2019 branded postpaid net additions target to 3.1mln to 3.7mln (prev. 2.6mln to 3.6mln), reiterates 2019 adj EBITDA guidance (12.7bln-13.2bln).
  • Verisign (VRSN) (Technology/Internet Content & Information) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 1.31 (exp. 1.25), revenue 0.306bln (exp. 0.3bln).

OTHER

  • AstraZeneca (AZN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) (USD) Q1 EPS 0.47 (exp. 0.42), reiterates FY19 core EPS at 3.50-3.70. FY19 cash performance expected to be adversely impacted by a number of one-off payments relating to prior business-development transactions (many of these payments was made in Q1). Co. remains committed to focusing on appropriate cash generating and value-accretive collaboration and divestment transactions. Core operating profit seen increasing by a mid-teens vs. FY18, capex seen broadly stable, restructuring expenses targeted to reduce vs. the prior year.
  • Goodyear Tires (GT) (Consumer Cyclical/Rubber & Plastics) (USD) Q1 adj EPS 0.19 (exp. 0.06), revenue 3.6bln (est. 3.74bln).
  • Uber (UBER) (Information Technology/Software) IPO price range USD 44-50 per share, sources said, would value co. between USD 80-90bln. Uber to raise between 8-10bln from the listing. The co. reported 2018 gross bookings rose to USD 49.8bln (+45% Y/Y), revenue USD 11.3bln (+42% Y/Y), and adds that there were 1.5bln trips on the platform in the quarter ending 31/Dec.
  • US Auto Names (F, GM, FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Autos) Daimler (DAI GY) sees slight growth in unit sales, revenue, earnings for 2019. Renault (RNO FP) plans to propose a merger with partner Nissan (7201 JP, NSANY) under a new holding company, in which both automakers would receive an approximately 50% stake.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 26th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European indices are little changed with the markets focus remaining firmly on earnings
  • On the trade front it has been reported that if a deal is finalised, Chinese President Xi could sign the deal in the US as early as June
  • Brent and WTI prices have extended on losses this morning, with some citing this to technical factors
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US GDP (Advance)
  • Earnings: Exxon Mobil, Colgate, Chevron, American Airlines

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac risk sentiment was mostly downbeat as markets remained heavily focused on earnings releases and following the lacklustre performance of counterparts stateside. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) were both subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector after a pullback in oil prices although losses in the broader market were only marginal and the index eventually recovered, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured amid a slew of earnings and following disappointing Industrial Production figures with participants also reducing exposure ahead of a 10-day closure for Golden Week. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) opened lower as PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 300bln liquidity drain for the week but with losses in Hong Kong later pared amid earnings including China Life Insurance which almost doubled its Q1 net from the prior year. Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices underpinned by the mostly risk-averse tone and BoJ presence for JPY 480bln of JGBs in the belly.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 300bln vs. last week's CNY 300bln net injection. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7307 (Prev. 6.7307)

 

US President Trump suggested that Chinese President Xi will be visiting the White House soon. In other news, the US is considering concessions on drug protection in talks with China after the latter was said to offer 8 years of IP protections for biologics data vs. 12 years under current US law. (Newswires) Subsequently reported that, Chinese President Xi could travel to the US to sign a trade deal as soon as June; if the two sides finalise a trade deal., SCMP citing sources. (SCMP)

Chinese President Xi said China will open its market up to more firms and continue to erode backward as well as outdated capacity, while he also stated that China will increase imports and will not pursue CNY depreciation that harms others. (Newswires)

 

Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) M/M -0.9% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -4.6% vs. Exp. -3.8% (Prev. -1.1%)

 

Japanese Tokyo CPI (Apr) Y/Y 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 0.9%). (Newswires)

Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Apr) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Apr) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

 

RBNZ Governor Orr said not particularly worried by slower pace of growth and pointed to a strong labour market, while he added that there is room to cut rates if needed. (Newswires) New Zealand Trade Balance (Mar) M/M 922M vs. Exp. 131M (Prev. 12M, Rev. -68M). (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (Mar) 5.70B vs. Exp. 5.30B (Prev. 4.82B, Rev. 4.71B) New Zealand Imports (Mar) 4.77B vs. Exp. 5.15B (Prev. 4.80B, Rev. 4.78B)

 

US

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he sees the Fed moving towards cutting rates and reiterated support for Stephen Moore to the Fed. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK officials have conceded that UK PM May does not have enough time to ger her Brexit deal passed by Parliament and avoid taking part in EU elections. (Newswires) 

UK PM May spokesperson says that more talks will happen with Labour next week. (newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond says he has a "productive" meeting with his labour counterpart in a meeting, and optimistic they can reach a common ground albeit necessitating compromise from both sides. (Newswires)

French President Macron said he wants to significantly cut income tax which will be funded by closing tax loopholes, spending cuts and making the French work more. Furthermore, Macron said the tax cuts would be worth EUR 5bln and that the French must work longer because they live longer but doesn't want to push back the retirement age beyond 62. (Newswires)

SNB's Jordan says they stand ready to use negative rates and intervention on FX market as and where appropriate. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn states that long-lasting slow inflation may have lowered inflation targets, markets may see that in current conditions monetary policy measures are not sufficient to accelerate inflation, decline in inflation expectations may be attributed to asymmetry in the ECB's definition of price stability. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed but little changed overall [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%], with sectors portraying a similar scene; notably, the Oil & Gas sector is underperforming in-line with the recent downturn in oil prices and with sector heavyweights Total’s (-0.4%) broadly as expected earnings unable to counter the downward pressure. After an earning fuelled morning the FTSE 100 (-0.3%) is somewhat lagging its peers with the index weighed on predominantly by RBS (-4.4%) in-spite of the Co’s beat on Q1 profit before tax, as the Co. stated that the ongoing impact of Brexit uncertainty is likely to impact income growth in the near term. Glencore (-3.0%) and Just Eat (-3.2%) are also weighing on the FTSE 100 after the CFTC stated they are investigating if the Co’s units violated CFTC regulations and as UK Q1 orders increased by only 7.4% respectively. Other notable movers include Deutsche Bank (-3.0%) are lagging the Dax (+0.1%) after the Co. cut their FY19 sales outlook and they expect FY19 revenue to be flat. Elsewhere, Renault (+3.0%) posted Q1 revenue in-line with expectations and confirmed their guidance for FY19.

Another FAANG member showed their teeth after yesterday’s blowout number from FB, wherein Amazon beat EPS expectations by over USD 3 and didn’t sacrifice this gain in their revenue print, which came in marginally above expectations. This came as web services revenue increased by over 40% with the company reporting their most profitable quarter ever. Clouds remain on the horizon after the bright earnings, however, as the company warned of a slower Q2. In the pre-market AMZN are trading with gains of 1%.

 

On the flipside, Intel short-circuited and reported shockingly bad earnings guidance despite top and bottom line printing inline with expectations. The hardware maker cut their FY guidance and forecast a weak Q2 as Chinese data centre sales remain soft, as the region is consuming fewer microchips than expected, and follows on from a similar warning sign eschewed from Texas Instruments.  As a result of the terrible results INTC are trading with losses of 7% in the pre-market.

 

FX

NZD/SEK - The Kiwi and Swedish Krona are leading a comeback of sorts vs a still solid Greenback that is holding above the 98.000 handle in DXY terms and Fib support just shy of the big figure (97.961), with data providing respite for both G10 currencies in the form of NZ trade and Swedish retail sales. Nzd/Usd has subsequently extended its rebound through 0.6600 to just over 0.6650, with the added impetus of relatively upbeat rhetoric from RBNZ Orr overnight, while Eur/Sek has retreated further from post-Riksbank peaks and back below 10.6000 as the single currency lags amidst dovish remarks from ECB’s Rehn.

AUD - Another major beneficiary of short covering and position paring in advance of US growth and PCE price gauges, as the Aussie recovers more ground from sub-0.7000 levels vs its US peer towards 0.7040, albeit still trading heavily on a Aud/Nzd cross basis under 1.0600 following weak Q1 CPI data earlier in the week that ramped up RBA easing expectations.

EUR - As noted above, the Euro has been hampered to a degree by Rehn comments adding a bit more credence to sourced reports suggesting that some GC members are inclined towards shifting guidance on rate normalisation out further than the current end of 2019 or later to a BoJ-style next year. Hence, Eur/Usd’s bounce from yesterday’s new ytd low (circa 1.1116) has been stymied ahead of 1.1150 and decent option expiries stretching to 1.1160 (1.5 bn), while residual bids above 1.1100 may also be supplemented by hedging or buying interest linked to a total of 1 bn running off at the strike.

GBP/CHF/CAD/JPY - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd as Cable pivots 1.2900 awaiting more Brexit developments and eyeing next week’s super BoE Thursday, while the Franc continues to straddle 1.0200 and meander between 1.1375-50 against the single currency in wake of yet another reminder from the SNB that NIRP and FX intervention are still warranted. The Loonie is still managing to hold above post-BoC lows and above 1.3500 even though crude prices are recoiling further from best levels in the run up to Canadian budget balances for February. Elsewhere, Usd/Jpy remains rangebound below 112.00 and just over chart support sub-111.40 in the form of the 30 DMA and a 61.8% Fib (at 111.37 to be precise), with the upside also capped by 1.1 bn option expiries from 112.00-20, and the impending long Japanese holiday still drawing attention as a potential hazard given the so called flash crash in currency and other markets when Japan was absent earlier this year.

EM - A double-whammy for the Rouble on the aforementioned pronounced downturn in oil and with speculation that the CBR could take a lead from other Central Banks along a dovish policy path. Usd/Rub currently trading closer to the top of 64.8310-5630 parameters.

FIXED INCOME

Bonds remain firmer and curves flatter (just) as the focus shifts to the US open and first look at growth in Q1, with Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries all holding light gains. However, the 10 year benchmarks are all some distance from best levels of 165.92, 127.80 and 123-17+ respectively as the next/nearest set of chart resistance levels stalled further advances towards 166.00, 128.00 and 2.50% in yield terms in the case of T-notes. Note also, the US curve has also absorbed more 2-30 year spread widening flow.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-1.3%) and WTI (-1.3%) prices are firmly in the red with prices dropping below the USD 75/bbl and USD 65/bbl levels; notably, Brent had only reached the USD 75/bbl level yesterday for the first time this year. Iran’s crude oil exports from their Southern Ports have reportedly increased so far in April to 3.56mln BPD; specifically, regarding the Iranian oil waivers, Turkey are attempting to convince the US to allow Turpas to continue the purchase of oil from Iran. For reference, under the import waivers Turkey was permitted to import around 60kBPD of oil from Iran, and in December a total of around 54k BPD of oil was imported by Turkey from Iran. Elsewhere, following reports that a number of refineries had suspended the import of Russian oil from the Druzhba pipeline (1.2mln BPD) due to contamination issues, Russia has stated that the issues will be resolved from April 29th. However, reports indicate that some of the refineries that have suspended imports believe the problem will continue for another one or two weeks.

Gold (+0.4%) prices have gradually moved higher across the session, benefitting from the cautious risk tone and concern ahead of Japan’s Golden Week holiday where markets will be closed for 10-days. Elsewhere, due to the softer dollar ahead of today’s GDP data, metal prices have retraced some of the prior session’s losses; and there were reports this morning of an explosion at Port Talbot, which is the UK’s largest steelworks. Tata Steel, who own the site, stated that there were no serious injuries and an investigation is ongoing.

Iranian Oil Minister Zanganeh states that the UAE and Saudi Arabia are overstating their oil reserves., according to state news. (Newswires)

subject: PREVIEW: Exxon Mobil (XOM) earnings due 0800 EDT/1300 BST
content:
• Q1 EPS (USD): 0.69.
  • Q1 REVENUE (USD): 64.82bln.
  • EXPECTED FY 2019 EPS/REVENUE (USD): 4.37 and 283.47bln.
  • OPTIONS-IMPLIED PRICE SWING: +/- 1.5%
  • CONSTITUENT: DJIA (weight: 2.0%), SPX (weight: 1.4%)
  • SECTOR: Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas. Peers: CVX, HES.
  • PREVIOUS CLOSE (USD): 82.22
  • MEAN ANALYST PRICE TARGET (USD): 85.39
  • ANALYSTS: Of 22 analysts covering XOM, 3 rate it a strong buy, 3 rate it a buy, 14 rate it a hold, 1 rates it a sell, 1 rate it a strong sell.
  • FACTORS: Earlier this month, ahead of earnings, XOM released quarterly guidance for the first time, which analysts have interpreted as a sign that management is attempting to increase transparency. Goldman Sachs analysts note that the key risks to XOM now relate to capital spending levels (expenses guided within USD 700-900mln; margin improvement is gradually expected to come as XOM drives production of higher value products; absence of asset sales in Germany and Italy to drive a negative USD 900mln impact to refining net income, XOM said), commodity prices (XOM sees upstream production volumes around 4mln BOE/day, while the absence of a North American crude differential benefit seen in Q4 is to drive a negative USD 1.3bln impact to refining profits), as well as project execution.

Source: Goldman Sachs, RANsquawk, Refinitiv.

NOTE: RANsquawk is trialling this new format for US earnings previews and would welcome your feedback. For the Q1 2019 earnings season, we will be using this format to preview earnings for companies listed on the Dow Jones Industrial Average only.

content: The 10 year UK benchmark continues to rebound from recent lows and claw back relative losses/underperformance vs Bunds especially, but also US Treasuries, albeit gradually and tentatively amidst the ongoing Brexit uncertainty and with the added risk of negative/bearish reviews from the ratings agencies later today (S&P and Fitch both slated to deliver latest assessments tonight). Indeed, the early Liffe range is pretty restrained between 127.63-73 vs yesterday’s 127.62 close, but from a chart perspective Gilts have breached Thursday’s session high in contrast to their Eurozone equivalent. Meanwhile, the 3 month strip has overcome a somewhat shaky start to sit 0.5-1 tick ahead before BBA mortgage applications and CBI industrial trends.

subject: Bunds: still butting up against resistance ahead of 166.00
content: Almost déjà vu for the core Eurozone bond that started Friday’s session on a former footing at 165.77, +8 ticks, but only extended gains to test/match yesterday’s 165.80 Eurex high before running into offers and retreating to a 165.65 low, close to technical support circa 165.67-68 (double bottom of sorts as it incorporates Thursday’s final 60 minute base and a 50% Fib of the day’s range). However, Bunds retain a relatively firm underlying bid as ECB and global Central Bank policy overall leans more dovishly, with Rehn also reportedly noting that some GC members are in favour of maintaining rates at current levels into 2020 vs official guidance through to the end of this year at least. Note also, any further underperformance in Italian BTPs and/or Spanish Bonos pre-ratings review and election respectively should keep the German 10 year benchmark underpinned along with month end and Japanese Golden Week positioning. Ahead, potentially more from ECB’s Rehn around 9.00BST and for option traders the expiry of May19 contracts.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

26th April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac risk sentiment was mostly downbeat as markets remained heavily focused on earnings releases and following the lacklustre performance of counterparts stateside. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were both subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector after a pullback in oil prices although losses in the broader market were only marginal and the index eventually recovered, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured amid a slew of earnings and following disappointing Industrial Production figures with participants also reducing exposure ahead of a 10-day closure for Golden Week. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) opened lower as PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 300bln liquidity drain for the week but with losses in Hong Kong later pared amid earnings including China Life Insurance which almost doubled its Q1 net from the prior year.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 26th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asia-Pac risk sentiment was mostly downbeat as markets remained heavily focused on earnings releases and following the lacklustre performance of counterparts stateside
  • UK officials have conceded that UK PM May does not have enough time to get her Brexit deal passed by Parliament and avoid taking part in EU elections
  • DXY consolidated after the prior day’s choppy price action but remained considerably firmer on the week and above the 98.00 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US GDP (Advance), SNB’s Jordan, ECB’s Rehn
  • Earnings: Exxon Mobil, Colgate, Chevron, American Airlines, Total, Deutsche Bank, Daimler, Sanofi, AstraZeneca

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac risk sentiment was mostly downbeat as markets remained heavily focused on earnings releases and following the lacklustre performance of counterparts stateside. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were both subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s energy sector after a pullback in oil prices although losses in the broader market were only marginal and the index eventually recovered, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured amid a slew of earnings and following disappointing Industrial Production figures with participants also reducing exposure ahead of a 10-day closure for Golden Week. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) opened lower as PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 300bln liquidity drain for the week but with losses in Hong Kong later pared amid earnings including China Life Insurance which almost doubled its Q1 net from the prior year. Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices underpinned by the mostly risk-averse tone and BoJ presence for JPY 480bln of JGBs in the belly.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 300bln vs. last week's CNY 300bln net injection. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7307 (Prev. 6.7307)

 

US President Trump suggested that Chinese President Xi will be visiting the White House soon. In other news, the US is considering concessions on drug protection in talks with China after the latter was said to offer 8 years of IP protections for biologics data vs. 12 years under current US law. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said China will open its market up to more firms and continue to erode backward as well as outdated capacity, while he also stated that China will increase imports and will not pursue CNY depreciation that harms others. (Newswires)

 

Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) M/M -0.9% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires) Japanese Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -4.6% vs. Exp. -3.8% (Prev. -1.1%)

 

Japanese Tokyo CPI (Apr) Y/Y 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 0.9%). (Newswires)

Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Apr) Y/Y 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Apr) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

UK/EU

UK officials have conceded that UK PM May does not have enough time to get her Brexit deal passed by Parliament and avoid taking part in EU elections. (Newswires)

 

French President Macron said he wants to significantly cut income tax which will be funded by closing tax loopholes, spending cuts and making the French work more. Furthermore, Macron said the tax cuts would be worth EUR 5bln and that the French must work longer because they live longer but doesn't want to push back the retirement age beyond 62. (Newswires)

FX

DXY consolidated after the prior day’s choppy price action but remained considerably firmer on the week and above the 98.00 level after headline Durable Goods surprised to the upside ahead of today’s GDP release, while some also suggested dovish pivots among the major central banks and tightening USD liquidity as factors restricting the downside for the hard currency. Nonetheless, most major pairs attempted to take advantage of the restrained greenback although the recovery was only mild with EUR/USD below 1.1150 and as GBP/USD only just about reclaimed the 1.2900 handle. Antipodeans were slightly firmer with NZD/USD underpinned by better than expected trade data and after RBNZ Governor Orr shrugged off slower growth concerns, while CNH also benefitted after the PBoC maintained the reference rate which was at a firmer setting then analysts had expected and after Chinese President Xi affirmed China will not pursue harmful currency depreciation. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses nursed some losses after having briefly slipped below 111.50 as well as its 100DMA and 200DMA levels ahead of the holiday closures, with Japanese retail investors’ net long JPY positions vs. USD at near-record levels amid flash crash and volatility fears due to expectation of reduced liquidity in Japan’s upcoming prolonged absence.

RBNZ Governor Orr said not particularly worried by slower pace of growth and pointed to a strong labour market, while he added that there is room to cut rates if needed. (Newswires) New Zealand Trade Balance (Mar) M/M 922M vs. Exp. 131M (Prev. 12M, Rev. -68M). (Newswires) New Zealand Exports (Mar) 5.70B vs. Exp. 5.30B (Prev. 4.82B, Rev. 4.71B) New Zealand Imports (Mar) 4.77B vs. Exp. 5.15B (Prev. 4.80B, Rev. 4.78B)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed with the energy complex underperforming as Brent crude pulled back from the prior day’s YTD highs and with WTI crude slipping further to below the USD 65.00/bbl level amid touted profit taking and some overhang from this week bearish inventory reports. Conversely, UBS have noted that market focus remains on the supply/demand outlook and geopolitical tensions, while Citi suggested it is hard to argue against higher oil prices amid tighter supply from sanctions on Iran and Venezuela despite US assurances. Elsewhere, gold prices eked mild gains and copper nursed some of the prior day’s losses as the greenback took breather from recent advances and as focus now shifts to upcoming US GDP data. 

US President Trump’s offshore oil-drilling plan sidelined indefinitely as the Interior Department grapples with a recent court decision that blocks Arctic drilling, according to reports citing Interior Secretary David Bernhardt. (WSJ)

Iraq's crude oil exports from the southern ports rise in the 3 three weeks of April to 3.56mln BPD, according to Petro-Logistics. (Newswires)

Shell workers unions agreed to a new wage offer to end strikes at the Pernis refinery. (Newswires)

US

It was a subdued session ahead of today’s GDP data, as well as the FOMC and NFP next week. Durable goods data was mixed, but some bank desks raised their trackers ahead of tomorrow's Q1 GDP print, suggesting that there might be some upside to the 2.1% consensus view for Q1. Some have noted that the Atlanta Fed GDP tracker was revised lower slightly after the data, but it is still worth pointing out that it was tracking zero growth at the beginning of the year, and now at 2.7%, suggests that the quarter was not as bad as had been feared in January, as risk sentiment soured, and the Fed subsequently pivoted dovish. Nevertheless, Treasury yields were flattish on Thursday, with a slight bias towards higher. The US sold 7yr paper in an average auction; a tail of 0.5bps bucks this week's trend of 'on the screws' auctions; the indirect bid was eyed after the decent performance at the 5s auction on Wednesday, and although it slipped slightly, it was still slightly better than the three auction average -- some have speculated that high US hedging costs could see foreign bidders participate in US auctions unhedged, which might provide support for the buck. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not significant. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4+ ticks lower at 123-12.

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said he sees the Fed moving towards cutting rates and reiterated support for Stephen Moore to the Fed. (Newswires)

White House is reportedly pushing for action to raise the debt ceiling with the requests said to be taking on urgency as other discussions in Capitol Hill have broken down. (Newswires)

(-0.5%) opened lower as PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 300bln liquidity drain for the week but with losses in Hong Kong later pared amid earnings including China Life Insurance which almost doubled its Q1 net from the prior year.

In FX markets, DXY has consolidated after the prior day’s choppy price action but remains considerably firmer on the week and above the 98.00 level after headline Durable Goods surprised to the upside ahead of today’s GDP release, with some also suggesting dovish pivots among the major central banks and tightening USD liquidity as factors restricting the downside for the hard currency. Nonetheless, most major pairs attempt to take advantage of the restrained greenback but with the recovery only mild with EUR/USD still below 1.1150 and as GBP/USD only just about reclaimed the 1.2900 handle. Antipodeans are slightly firmer with NZD/USD underpinned by better than expected trade data and after RBNZ Governor Orr suggested he was not concerned regarding slower pace of growth, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses attempt to nurse losses after having briefly slipped below 111.50 as well as its 100DMA and 200DMA levels ahead of the holiday closures with Japanese retail investors’ net long JPY positions vs. USD at near-record levels amid flash crash and volatility fears from reduced liquidity in Japan’s upcoming absence.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher with prices supported by the risk averse tone and BoJ presence for JPY 480bln of JGBs in the belly.
